abstracts.cdata!:
The project gave mixed results, for
            although the assessment of outcome is satisfactory, and the
            institutional development impact substantial, sustainability
            is unlikely given the general socioeconomic situation, and,
            both performances were rated unsatisfactory, due to the lack
            of strong Bank financial management skills, which hindered
            supervision, and, the Government's weak implementing
            agencies. Among the many lessons learned, it is suggested
            that AIDS has to be addressed massively, and in a
            multi-sectoral manner, for the project clearly shows that
            the narrow health focus, and the emphasis on
            pharmaceuticals, made the project - though relevant - an
            insufficient instrument in the fight against the epidemic.
            Moreover, although simplicity in project design is often
            praised, this made it dependent on parallel financing of
            programmatic aspects; seemingly, such dependency can only be
            allowed if either the Government, or the Bank takes
            responsibility for supporting lagging components, or if
            sector-wide arrangements are established. Consequently, the
            project functioned well as a complementary project, but was
            too narrow in scope to function on its own. In addition,
            procurement of drugs, or supplies should be cognizant of the
            multiple uses of such items, thus the requirement for these
            to be strictly for "project related" purposes,
            undermines the efficiency in the health system.
